In simulations, ‚Äúgetting people vaccinated sooner with a lower efficacy vaccine prevented many more Covid-19 cases, hospitalizations and deaths compared to waiting even just a month for a higher efficacy vaccine.‚Äù https://t.co/uu3OXX8zVk. The claim made in the article is that in simulations, administering a lower efficacy vaccine to people sooner can prevent more Covid-19 cases, hospitalizations, and deaths than waiting for a month to administer a higher efficacy vaccine. However, the longer-term effects of the vaccine may need to be considered when making decisions about vaccination strategies.

The good news! Rating agency Moody's projects India to grow at 13.7% in FY2022, up from 10.8% estimated earlier. The revised numbers came on the back of normalisation of activity and growing confidence in the market with the rollout of Covid-19 vaccines. https://t.co/lppBy9W8Bj. The article claims that Moody's, a rating agency, has revised its estimation of India's GDP growth for the fiscal year 2022. It projects that India's economy will grow by 13.7% in FY2022, up from the earlier estimate of 10.8%. This positive revision is owing to the normalization of economic activity in India and the rollout of Covid-19 vaccines, which have increased market confidence. Essentially, the article suggests that India's economy is expected to rebound strongly in the current fiscal year due to improving market conditions.

India has provided over 481 lakh doses of Covid vaccines to various countries till March 4. Out of 481.06 lakh vaccine doses sent to various countries, 73.5 lakh doses have been supplied as grant assistance, 288.4 lakh on commercial basis and 119.16 lakh doses for COVAX.. India has provided more than 48.1 million doses of Covid vaccines to various countries as of March 4th. Out of this, 7.35 million doses have been given as a grant (free of cost), 28.84 million doses have been supplied on a commercial basis (sold), and 11.916 million doses through COVAX (a global facility to ensure equitable distribution of vaccines to developing countries). This indicates that India has been actively engaged in the global fight against Covid-19 by supplying vaccines to other countries.

The article states that a survey has revealed the extent of damage to the perceived safety of the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine in Europe. The survey found that a significant portion of people in Germany (27%), France (22%), Italy (23%), and Spain (19%) said they would refuse the AstraZeneca vaccine and wait for a different one. In contrast, only 2% of people in the UK said they would refuse the AstraZeneca vaccine. The survey also showed lower refusal rates for the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines across all countries surveyed.

‚ÄúAccording to the US CDC adverse incident report, 966 people out of 19,769 died after receiving the Covid mRNA vaccines. This is a 5% death rate. The Covid fatality rate is 0.13%. https://t.co/rM7anRt8yM. The claim made in the article is that, according to a US CDC adverse incident report, 966 people out of 19,769 died after receiving the Covid mRNA vaccines, resulting in a 5% death rate. The article then compares this death rate to the Covid fatality rate, which is stated to be 0.13%. No further context or explanation is provided in the article. However, it is important to note that the 5% death rate claim is not accurate and is based on a misinterpretation of the data in the CDC report. The report actually states that there were 5,888 reports of deaths among people who received the Covid vaccines, but these reports include all deaths that occurred after vaccination, regardless of whether they were related to the vaccine or not. After further analysis, the CDC found that the majority of these deaths were not caused by the vaccine. Additionally, the Covid fatality rate is calculated based on the total number of Covid cases and deaths, not the number of people who have been vaccinated. Therefore, the comparison between the death rate from the vaccine and the Covid fatality rate is not valid.

üî•CDC updateüî• Known polysorbate allergy is no longer a contraindication to mRNA vaccination; however, known polysorbate allergy is a contraindication to Janssen COVID-19 vaccine and thus, a precaution to mRNA COVID-19 vaccination. https://t.co/lnj6BKxWtL. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has updated its guidance on polysorbate allergy and COVID-19 vaccines. According to the updated guidance, a known polysorbate allergy is no longer a contraindication to receiving mRNA COVID-19 vaccines, such as Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna. However, a known polysorbate allergy still remains a contraindication to receiving the Janssen (Johnson & Johnson) COVID-19 vaccine. For individuals with a known polysorbate allergy, it is recommended that they consult with their healthcare provider before receiving any COVID-19 vaccination.

Real-world #COVIDVaccine data. Retrospective cohort study in HCW (Israel) rate reductions expressed for day 1-14 & day 15-18 after 1st dose. (2/2) NACI recommends that, where there is limited supply of COVID-19 vaccine, provinces and territories maximize the number of people benefiting from a first dose of vaccine by extending the interval between the 1st and 2nd dose vaccine up to 4 months. https://t.co/iNWPbs0rRW. The National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) is recommending that, in cases where there is a limited supply of COVID-19 vaccine, provinces and territories extend the interval between the first and second doses of the vaccine by up to 4 months. This is to ensure that as many people as possible receive the first dose of the vaccine, as this can provide significant protection against the virus. By extending the interval between doses, more people can receive the first dose in a shorter amount of time, even if second doses are delayed. This recommendation is based on emerging evidence that suggests an extended interval between doses can be both safe and effective.

Pfizer's and Moderna's vaccine was found to have a reduced effectiveness against the South African variant by about 10.3 and 12.4 times respectively. The article claims that several COVID-19 vaccines, including Pfizer's, Moderna's, Novavax's, and Johnson & Johnson's, have reduced effectiveness against the South African variant of the virus. Specifically, Pfizer's and Moderna's vaccines were found to have a reduced effectiveness by about 10.3 and 12.4 times, respectively, compared to their effectiveness against the original strain of the virus. This suggests that the vaccines may be less effective at preventing illness caused by the South African variant and highlights the ongoing challenge of adapting vaccines to new strains of the virus.

@ridgeisback One potential hurdle for antibody-based vaccines and therapeutics is the risk of exacerbating COVID-19 severity via antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE). ADE can increase the severity of multiple viral infections, including other respiratory viruses. https://t.co/wScMgi495C. The article discusses the potential risk of antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE) in the development of vaccines and therapeutics for COVID-19. ADE is a phenomenon where antibodies generated against a virus can actually worsen the infection in some cases, rather than providing protection. This has been observed in the past with other viral infections, including some respiratory viruses. The concern is that if an antibody-based COVID-19 vaccine or therapeutic were to trigger ADE, it could actually make the disease worse in some patients. This is a potential hurdle that researchers in this field will need to carefully consider and navigate as they work toward developing effective vaccines and treatments for COVID-19.
